_Oast Oag
A few birds singing, a National Bohemian beer can from last year,
and the first freshman arrives. These Baltimore birds were that
freshman's sole companions until the Office of Residential Life
opened at 9:00 a.m. Soon dozens of orange shirted orientation
workers emerged from the streets of Baltimore to drag the anxious
freshman from their more than anxious (almost neurotic in some
cases) parents. The male orientation workers, though stuffed with
free, stale, doughnuts were still hungry enough to scan the long lines
of waiting cars for glimpses of the incoming beauties from the
swamps of New Jersey. As those chosen few were divested of
everything of value, the others, in due time, were eventually
serviced.
Everyone was relieved of their prized possessions and it was the
same prized possessions every time;stereo, hairdryer, television, high
school I.D. card, posters, tennis racket, teddy bears, golf clubs,
potted plants, pot plants, high school yearbook, electric fan,lacrosse
sticks and Mom's last minute care packages.
Naturally, their most prized possessions, plants and student
Handbooks, were cradled in their hands. Much to each freshman's
relief, he or she was soon on his or her way to the dormitory,
ensuring that those precious popcorn poppers made their way to

their rooms while those shrewd orientation workers were pushing
Mom and Dad toward the distant parking fields of Garland Hall. Left
in the room, these desperately brave neophytes confronted their
grimy, miniscule, unpainted cages and promptly went into catatonia.
Adding insult to injury, if the room wasn't enough, there was the
roommate. Moment of silence. Sigh. (Mental Note: "Next year be
sure to insist upon a single room .... At least I got the bed I wanted
... You certainly don't look like your handwriting.")
Words started to sputter out.
"I only tolerate classical music."
"You mean Chuck Berry?"
"Well, maybe we can't be friends, but we'll get along."
"I go to bed at 11 o'clock."
"No problem so long as you can sleep with the lights and
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart on."
"Who?"
"Did you vote for Ford too?"
"I'm a meteorology major."
"Pre-Harvard."
"Is the math department really that bad?"
Continued on page ten

One hundred years of moving-in
The bleakest moment of freshman year is the instant the
unsuspecting novice first sees the black hole snikeringly called by the
tourist brochures as "the dorm room." At first you want to cry your
eyes out, but then your hysteria dies down and you ask the
orientation cherub where to go to get your refund. Gradually,
however, your senses come back, and in a few days, you begin to
realize how John Mitchell must feel living in a minimum security
prision camp.
If it's any comfort, countless freshmen have felt the same way
throughout the century-old ritual of moving-in at Hopkins. Take,
for instance, the vision of Woodrow Wilson (Ph.D.'86) moving into
his lodgings a ramshackle rooming hourse near the original Hopkins
campus where the Walters Art Gallery now squats. Over his bony
shoulder is slung a long canvas bag filled with hickory shafted golf
clubs and music from his Glee Club days at Princeton. Behind him a
porter carrying a large trunk on his back puffs his way up the narrow
stairs and manages to gasp, "Is we here yet, Mistuh Wilson?"
"No, not quite," answers Woody (as his friends call him) with a
peculiar glint in his eyes that could only recall the twenty bricks he
had packed in the trunk as a ruse on the aged blackamoor.
In a matter of minutes they reach the loft where they find one
Phineas Beanstock (of the Boston Beanstocks) stretched lazily on
the ostremoor. "Do you wish to join me in a cup of tea, my dear
boy?"
"I don't think there's enough room for both us, you malicious
wiseacre," chortles Woody,"and you, Jones, place that trunk in a safe
spot.''
"Dere's no safe spot in Mobtown, Mistuh Wilson," grunts the
porter.
"Oh dear me," sighs Woody, "I am begining to think Baltimore is

as barbarous as I thought it was. And 1 didn't bring an interpreter.
along." And we last see Woody Wilson getting himself a cup of tea
and fortifying it with several jiggers of Jack Daniels.
Then there is the celebrated case of Frank "Mugsy" Muldoon (of
the Southside Muldoons) who tried to sneak a still into his room in
1927, scarely a year after the Old dorms were opened. Mugsy had a
good head for business and knew his sour mash enterprise would pay
for his tuition many times over. Smuggling in the still was a very
easy matter; Mugsy painted the palms of the porters- with ten dollar
bills and slipped a Mickey Finn into the Dean's tea at an Orientation
luncheon. Let it be said that the class of '31 was the happiest on
record, despite the unfortunate Depression.
The Big Band Era was in full swing when an awkward teenager
with a foul mouth arrived from the wilds of West Baltimore to take
up residence in the dorms. His name was Spiro T. Agnew and his
career at Hopkins Lasted little more than a semester. From the start
it was obvious "Teddy" was a strange bird and unable to fit into the
Hopkins ideal. On his very first day here, he called his fellow
dOrmmates "impudent snobs, the motherfuckers," and complained
to anyone who would come close to him that there was no eatery in
the immediate area that served tunafish milkshakes.
Happier days were in store for Hopkins as the calendar flipped to
the fifties. The freshmen beanie was just large enough to contain the
consciousness of the. typical Hopkins student, as the file on Otis
McGuirk will show. Upon his arrival, Otis went into a tissy when he
learned that Hopkins had no Civil Defense Plan, that the nearest
bomb shelter to the dorms was Gilman Hall. "That's nearly two
hundred yards," the paranoid cried. Well, poor Otis couldn't take
the anxiety and he left school after Thanksgiving to become a
conductor on the Philadelphia subway system.

EJAYS*BLUEJAYS*BLU
A History of Homewood Sports
By Andrew Cohen

For many years the game of Lacrosse has been
synonymous with sports at Johns Hopkins. In
recent years, though, strong finishes by the
baseball, swimming, basketball, and soccer teams,
as well as new entries from the growing women's
athletic department have taken some of the
limelight from the perennial contending laxers.

L

ooking back, it was exactly 42 years ago
when Johns Hopkins began its first year with
a collegiate sports program on the amateur
level. In doing so, they accepted the
philosophy of the then University President
Ames who believed that college athletics
existed for all students and not just the
talented few. Up until 1935, Hopkins had
been part of the increasing
commercialization of intercollegiate sports
by offering huge scholarships and guarantees
to star athletes and charging steep admission
rates to all spectators.
Today, according to Director of Athletics
Robert Scott, this philosophy of "sports for
all" remains central to the Hopkins program.
Johns Hopkins continues as one of the only
schools of its caliber not offering an athletic
scholarship program. It should also be noted
that all Blue Jay sporting events, with the
exception of lacrosse, will go without an
admission fee in 1977-78.
Another major date was January, 1965,
the month in which the Newton H. White
Athletic Center opened its doors to the
Hopkins community. Named after Colonel
Newton White, a philanthropic friend of the
University, the center has served as a focal
point for all the athletic as well as much of
the social life that has occured here over the
past 12 years. The Athletic Center continues
to be a meeting ground for all, open daily 10
a.m.-10 p.m., Sundays, 1 p.m.-9 p.m.
Over the past ten years lacrosse has
dominated the Hopkins sports scene, and
rightfully so, due to its many successes. In
1968, Coach Robert Scott put together one
of the finest teams in Hopkin's illustrious lax
history. Led by all-American Downie
McCarty, Phil Kneip, and Joe Cowan, the
Jays ran roughshod over all opponents,
defeating Maryland 10-8 in the
championship game. The 1969 season saw
defensemen Mike Clark and Paul Weiss take
charge, sending the Blue Jays to their second
straight championship, this time sharing the
honors with West Point.
After fighting off some lean years in '70
and '71 and losing in the final to Maryland
in '72 and '73 the Jays finally brought the
crown back to Homewood with an
incredible 17-12 championship win over the
Terps in 1974. The Hopkins lax team came
close to taking another championship just
last year, but was overpowered by a strong
Cornell team 16-8 in the season's finale.
The exploits of the swimming team over
the past few years have offered reasons for
student cheer. In 1970, under the reigns of
Frank Comfort, an outstanding coach who
has since left for North Carolina, the
swimmers won the Middle Atlantic

Conference and Mason-Dixon
championships, defeating perennial winner
Catholic University. Since then, Blue Jay
swimmers have never failed to take these
championships and, in fact, have continued
to move forward in the NCAA College
Division, taking that championship just last
year. The list of individual all-Americans on
the Jay squad continues to grow, with such
names as Bill Milne, Mark Horning, Mike
Bay, and Maria Mock.
The Hopkins baseball team completed
their most successful season in history in
1977. For the first time the Blue Jay nine,
under the guidance of coach Dennis Cox,
finished first in the Southeast Division of the
Middle Atlantic Conference, defeating a
highly acclaimed Widener team in the finals
by the score of 2-1. Stars of both the
successful 1976 and 1977 teams, Dave
Emala and Dave Lewing were named to the
Academic all-American team of 1977. Emala
has since been signed by the Baltimore
Orioles and is playing in the minor leagues.
Recent football at Hopkins reached its
peak under Coach Denny Cox from
1971-1973. In those seasons, led by Jack
Thomas and Bill Nolan, the team posted
consecutive 5-3 records with notable
victories over arch rival Western Maryland.
1974-1977 saw the quality of play drop as
the team ran up consecutive 3-5 records.
According to Coach Cox, though, the future
holds pleasant surprises.
Soccer at Hopkins was never considered
to be a significant sport until Coach Bob
Oliver turned out a championship team in

1976. Led by top scorers Greg Cunningham
and Joe Rutkowski and goalie Ken Seusse,
the team compliled a record breaking 15-3-1
mark and was declared Middle Atlantic
Southern Division Champions.
The Blue Jay basketball team began to
take shape when Coach Gary Rupert entered
the scene in 1970. "That championship
season" came in 1973-74 when the cagers
took the Middle States championship with
an outstanding 17-7 record. Top scorer Bob
Friedman, key assist man John Rutter, and
top rebounder Bill Jews,led the way.
Other varsity sports such as fencing,
wrestling, track and field, cross country, and
tennis have continued to offer fan interest
throughout the past ten years.
A woman's program developed in 1971 by
Dr. Joyce Hogan and now under the
leadership of Micul Morse has grown to the
point where the women athletes of Hopkins
are today competing successfully in the areas
of fencing, tennis, swimming, squash,
basketball, field hockey, and lacrosse. Such
female stars as olympic swimmer Maria
Mock and junior olympic fencer Lori
Kelleher have come up through the Hopkins
program.
Indeed Johns Hopkins has had a glorious
history in the athletic world. For along with
all the championships the University has
collected, it has uniquely remained steadfast
in its philosophy that sports are for all to
enjoy and the University is not to be made,
as Dr. Wilson Shaffer wrote in his recent
book, "a pawn of promotional activities that
make (them) simply public entertainment".

"Everyone's from Long Island and they are all pre-meds."
"Baltimore's trashy, but it isn't as trashy as New York."
"The walls are bare. It's like a prison almost."
"Did you bring your teddy bear?"
"No, I brought my elephant."
"I think college can be a great learning experience."
[Hopkins pre-med]
"When does Goucher start?"
"Are the boys at Hopkins as lively as the boys at your high
school?"
"Well, they don't have much spunk in them."

Tuition

fl

BY ROBERT RIGGS

F

reshmen at Hopkins can expect tuition in future years to
demonstrate only one trend: "up," says Budget Director Norman
Krueger.
This rise will be only in dollar terms, not in real purchasing power
as measured by the Consumer Price Index. For example, this year,
tuition is $3750 for undergraduates, a rise of $250 over the
preceeding year. This is an increase of about 6%. Over the same
period, the estimated rate of inflation was also about 6%, so the
value of tuition this year is nearly the same as it was last year.
The real dollar cost to Hopkins students and their families has
been close to level over the last decade. In 1966-67, tuition was
$1825. Measured in 1967 dollars, last year's cost ($3500) would
amount to $1, 987, an increase of less than 1%. The real value of
Hopkins' tuition has actually declined from a peak in 1971-72, when
the fee of $2700 would have valued $2190 in 1967 dollars.
TuitiOn for 1978-79 is projected to be about $3950, with the
administration holding the figure under $4000 until 1979-80. By the
time today's freshmen are seniors, tuition will probably be about
$4500.

According to Krueger, tuition is one of the first items determined
during the annual Hopkins budget procedure. In addition to the
projected inflation rate, competitiveness with other private
universities is considered before a final figure is reached. Other
private institutions around the country are feeling the same
inflationary squeeze. Indeed, Hopkins may hold the line In
1975-76, tuition here was $3300. Last year, it went to $3500, an
increment of $200. Over the same period, tuition at Yale rose from
$4050 to $4400; at the University of Pennsylvania it soared from
$3790 to $4125; at Amherst, it increased from $3795 to $3975; and
at Tufts it went from $3550 to $3800.
The amount of tuition charged is made with input from many
people in the administration. Krueger describes it as "one of the
hardest thought out decisions we make around here. We don't want
to be the front-runner with tuition increases, but we just can't afford
to lag."
Young people today should not fear the astronomical costs
projected for educating children in twenty years, says Krueger.
"People's incomes today are not what they were ten years ago.
Education still takes, and will still take, the same percentage of a
family's income..., student aid has also tried to keep up with higher
costs."

_Oast Oag
A few birds singing, a National Bohemian beer can from last year,
and the first freshman arrives. These Baltimore birds were that
freshman's sole companions until the Office of Residential Life
opened at 9:00 a.m. Soon dozens of orange shirted orientation
workers emerged from the streets of Baltimore to drag the anxious
freshman from their more than anxious (almost neurotic in some
cases) parents. The male orientation workers, though stuffed with
free, stale, doughnuts were still hungry enough to scan the long lines
of waiting cars for glimpses of the incoming beauties from the
swamps of New Jersey. As those chosen few were divested of
everything of value, the others, in due time, were eventually
serviced.
Everyone was relieved of their prized possessions and it was the
same prized possessions every time;stereo, hairdryer, television, high
school I.D. card, posters, tennis racket, teddy bears, golf clubs,
potted plants, pot plants, high school yearbook, electric fan,lacrosse
sticks and Mom's last minute care packages.
Naturally, their most prized possessions, plants and student
Handbooks, were cradled in their hands. Much to each freshman's
relief, he or she was soon on his or her way to the dormitory,
ensuring that those precious popcorn poppers made their way to

their rooms while those shrewd orientation workers were pushing
Mom and Dad toward the distant parking fields of Garland Hall. Left
in the room, these desperately brave neophytes confronted their
grimy, miniscule, unpainted cages and promptly went into catatonia.
Adding insult to injury, if the room wasn't enough, there was the
roommate. Moment of silence. Sigh. (Mental Note: "Next year be
sure to insist upon a single room .... At least I got the bed I wanted
... You certainly don't look like your handwriting.")
Words started to sputter out.
"I only tolerate classical music."
"You mean Chuck Berry?"
"Well, maybe we can't be friends, but we'll get along."
"I go to bed at 11 o'clock."
"No problem so long as you can sleep with the lights and
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart on."
"Who?"
"Did you vote for Ford too?"
"I'm a meteorology major."
"Pre-Harvard."
"Is the math department really that bad?"
Continued on page ten

One hundred years of moving-in
The bleakest moment of freshman year is the instant the
unsuspecting novice first sees the black hole snikeringly called by the
tourist brochures as "the dorm room." At first you want to cry your
eyes out, but then your hysteria dies down and you ask the
orientation cherub where to go to get your refund. Gradually,
however, your senses come back, and in a few days, you begin to
realize how John Mitchell must feel living in a minimum security
prision camp.
If it's any comfort, countless freshmen have felt the same way
throughout the century-old ritual of moving-in at Hopkins. Take,
for instance, the vision of Woodrow Wilson (Ph.D.'86) moving into
his lodgings a ramshackle rooming hourse near the original Hopkins
campus where the Walters Art Gallery now squats. Over his bony
shoulder is slung a long canvas bag filled with hickory shafted golf
clubs and music from his Glee Club days at Princeton. Behind him a
porter carrying a large trunk on his back puffs his way up the narrow
stairs and manages to gasp, "Is we here yet, Mistuh Wilson?"
"No, not quite," answers Woody (as his friends call him) with a
peculiar glint in his eyes that could only recall the twenty bricks he
had packed in the trunk as a ruse on the aged blackamoor.
In a matter of minutes they reach the loft where they find one
Phineas Beanstock (of the Boston Beanstocks) stretched lazily on
the ostremoor. "Do you wish to join me in a cup of tea, my dear
boy?"
"I don't think there's enough room for both us, you malicious
wiseacre," chortles Woody,"and you, Jones, place that trunk in a safe
spot.''
"Dere's no safe spot in Mobtown, Mistuh Wilson," grunts the
porter.
"Oh dear me," sighs Woody, "I am begining to think Baltimore is

as barbarous as I thought it was. And 1 didn't bring an interpreter.
along." And we last see Woody Wilson getting himself a cup of tea
and fortifying it with several jiggers of Jack Daniels.
Then there is the celebrated case of Frank "Mugsy" Muldoon (of
the Southside Muldoons) who tried to sneak a still into his room in
1927, scarely a year after the Old dorms were opened. Mugsy had a
good head for business and knew his sour mash enterprise would pay
for his tuition many times over. Smuggling in the still was a very
easy matter; Mugsy painted the palms of the porters- with ten dollar
bills and slipped a Mickey Finn into the Dean's tea at an Orientation
luncheon. Let it be said that the class of '31 was the happiest on
record, despite the unfortunate Depression.
The Big Band Era was in full swing when an awkward teenager
with a foul mouth arrived from the wilds of West Baltimore to take
up residence in the dorms. His name was Spiro T. Agnew and his
career at Hopkins Lasted little more than a semester. From the start
it was obvious "Teddy" was a strange bird and unable to fit into the
Hopkins ideal. On his very first day here, he called his fellow
dOrmmates "impudent snobs, the motherfuckers," and complained
to anyone who would come close to him that there was no eatery in
the immediate area that served tunafish milkshakes.
Happier days were in store for Hopkins as the calendar flipped to
the fifties. The freshmen beanie was just large enough to contain the
consciousness of the. typical Hopkins student, as the file on Otis
McGuirk will show. Upon his arrival, Otis went into a tissy when he
learned that Hopkins had no Civil Defense Plan, that the nearest
bomb shelter to the dorms was Gilman Hall. "That's nearly two
hundred yards," the paranoid cried. Well, poor Otis couldn't take
the anxiety and he left school after Thanksgiving to become a
conductor on the Philadelphia subway system.

EJAYS*BLUEJAYS*BLU
A History of Homewood Sports
By Andrew Cohen

For many years the game of Lacrosse has been
synonymous with sports at Johns Hopkins. In
recent years, though, strong finishes by the
baseball, swimming, basketball, and soccer teams,
as well as new entries from the growing women's
athletic department have taken some of the
limelight from the perennial contending laxers.

L

ooking back, it was exactly 42 years ago
when Johns Hopkins began its first year with
a collegiate sports program on the amateur
level. In doing so, they accepted the
philosophy of the then University President
Ames who believed that college athletics
existed for all students and not just the
talented few. Up until 1935, Hopkins had
been part of the increasing
commercialization of intercollegiate sports
by offering huge scholarships and guarantees
to star athletes and charging steep admission
rates to all spectators.
Today, according to Director of Athletics
Robert Scott, this philosophy of "sports for
all" remains central to the Hopkins program.
Johns Hopkins continues as one of the only
schools of its caliber not offering an athletic
scholarship program. It should also be noted
that all Blue Jay sporting events, with the
exception of lacrosse, will go without an
admission fee in 1977-78.
Another major date was January, 1965,
the month in which the Newton H. White
Athletic Center opened its doors to the
Hopkins community. Named after Colonel
Newton White, a philanthropic friend of the
University, the center has served as a focal
point for all the athletic as well as much of
the social life that has occured here over the
past 12 years. The Athletic Center continues
to be a meeting ground for all, open daily 10
a.m.-10 p.m., Sundays, 1 p.m.-9 p.m.
Over the past ten years lacrosse has
dominated the Hopkins sports scene, and
rightfully so, due to its many successes. In
1968, Coach Robert Scott put together one
of the finest teams in Hopkin's illustrious lax
history. Led by all-American Downie
McCarty, Phil Kneip, and Joe Cowan, the
Jays ran roughshod over all opponents,
defeating Maryland 10-8 in the
championship game. The 1969 season saw
defensemen Mike Clark and Paul Weiss take
charge, sending the Blue Jays to their second
straight championship, this time sharing the
honors with West Point.
After fighting off some lean years in '70
and '71 and losing in the final to Maryland
in '72 and '73 the Jays finally brought the
crown back to Homewood with an
incredible 17-12 championship win over the
Terps in 1974. The Hopkins lax team came
close to taking another championship just
last year, but was overpowered by a strong
Cornell team 16-8 in the season's finale.
The exploits of the swimming team over
the past few years have offered reasons for
student cheer. In 1970, under the reigns of
Frank Comfort, an outstanding coach who
has since left for North Carolina, the
swimmers won the Middle Atlantic

Conference and Mason-Dixon
championships, defeating perennial winner
Catholic University. Since then, Blue Jay
swimmers have never failed to take these
championships and, in fact, have continued
to move forward in the NCAA College
Division, taking that championship just last
year. The list of individual all-Americans on
the Jay squad continues to grow, with such
names as Bill Milne, Mark Horning, Mike
Bay, and Maria Mock.
The Hopkins baseball team completed
their most successful season in history in
1977. For the first time the Blue Jay nine,
under the guidance of coach Dennis Cox,
finished first in the Southeast Division of the
Middle Atlantic Conference, defeating a
highly acclaimed Widener team in the finals
by the score of 2-1. Stars of both the
successful 1976 and 1977 teams, Dave
Emala and Dave Lewing were named to the
Academic all-American team of 1977. Emala
has since been signed by the Baltimore
Orioles and is playing in the minor leagues.
Recent football at Hopkins reached its
peak under Coach Denny Cox from
1971-1973. In those seasons, led by Jack
Thomas and Bill Nolan, the team posted
consecutive 5-3 records with notable
victories over arch rival Western Maryland.
1974-1977 saw the quality of play drop as
the team ran up consecutive 3-5 records.
According to Coach Cox, though, the future
holds pleasant surprises.
Soccer at Hopkins was never considered
to be a significant sport until Coach Bob
Oliver turned out a championship team in

1976. Led by top scorers Greg Cunningham
and Joe Rutkowski and goalie Ken Seusse,
the team compliled a record breaking 15-3-1
mark and was declared Middle Atlantic
Southern Division Champions.
The Blue Jay basketball team began to
take shape when Coach Gary Rupert entered
the scene in 1970. "That championship
season" came in 1973-74 when the cagers
took the Middle States championship with
an outstanding 17-7 record. Top scorer Bob
Friedman, key assist man John Rutter, and
top rebounder Bill Jews,led the way.
Other varsity sports such as fencing,
wrestling, track and field, cross country, and
tennis have continued to offer fan interest
throughout the past ten years.
A woman's program developed in 1971 by
Dr. Joyce Hogan and now under the
leadership of Micul Morse has grown to the
point where the women athletes of Hopkins
are today competing successfully in the areas
of fencing, tennis, swimming, squash,
basketball, field hockey, and lacrosse. Such
female stars as olympic swimmer Maria
Mock and junior olympic fencer Lori
Kelleher have come up through the Hopkins
program.
Indeed Johns Hopkins has had a glorious
history in the athletic world. For along with
all the championships the University has
collected, it has uniquely remained steadfast
in its philosophy that sports are for all to
enjoy and the University is not to be made,
as Dr. Wilson Shaffer wrote in his recent
book, "a pawn of promotional activities that
make (them) simply public entertainment".

Tuition

fl

BY ROBERT RIGGS

F

reshmen at Hopkins can expect tuition in future years to
demonstrate only one trend: "up," says Budget Director Norman
Krueger.
This rise will be only in dollar terms, not in real purchasing power
as measured by the Consumer Price Index. For example, this year,
tuition is $3750 for undergraduates, a rise of $250 over the
preceeding year. This is an increase of about 6%. Over the same
period, the estimated rate of inflation was also about 6%, so the
value of tuition this year is nearly the same as it was last year.
The real dollar cost to Hopkins students and their families has
been close to level over the last decade. In 1966-67, tuition was
$1825. Measured in 1967 dollars, last year's cost ($3500) would
amount to $1, 987, an increase of less than 1%. The real value of
Hopkins' tuition has actually declined from a peak in 1971-72, when
the fee of $2700 would have valued $2190 in 1967 dollars.
TuitiOn for 1978-79 is projected to be about $3950, with the
administration holding the figure under $4000 until 1979-80. By the
time today's freshmen are seniors, tuition will probably be about
$4500.

According to Krueger, tuition is one of the first items determined
during the annual Hopkins budget procedure. In addition to the
projected inflation rate, competitiveness with other private
universities is considered before a final figure is reached. Other
private institutions around the country are feeling the same
inflationary squeeze. Indeed, Hopkins may hold the line In
1975-76, tuition here was $3300. Last year, it went to $3500, an
increment of $200. Over the same period, tuition at Yale rose from
$4050 to $4400; at the University of Pennsylvania it soared from
$3790 to $4125; at Amherst, it increased from $3795 to $3975; and
at Tufts it went from $3550 to $3800.
The amount of tuition charged is made with input from many
people in the administration. Krueger describes it as "one of the
hardest thought out decisions we make around here. We don't want
to be the front-runner with tuition increases, but we just can't afford
to lag."
Young people today should not fear the astronomical costs
projected for educating children in twenty years, says Krueger.
"People's incomes today are not what they were ten years ago.
Education still takes, and will still take, the same percentage of a
family's income..., student aid has also tried to keep up with higher
costs."
